message: Participants receive lifetime access to 18 hours of live, interactive sessions, 10 hours of step-by-step coding instructions, a final project with direct feedback, 100 coding assignments, the entire source code of a working production system, access to a private community, direct access to the instructor, lifetime access to every past and future cohort, and a program certificate upon completion.
Yes, live sessions of the program are recorded.

The cost to join the program is $500 and it includes lifetime access to every past and future cohort, 18 hours of live interactive sessions, 10 hours of step-by-step coding instructions, a final project with feedback, 100 coding assignments, access to source code, a private community, direct access to the instructor, program certificate upon completion.
The cost associated with joining the program is $500, which is a one-time payment for lifetime access with no monthly fees, annual fees, or hidden costs.
The next cohort for the 'Building Machine Learning Systems That Don't Suck' program is on February 3 - 20, 2025.
Active learning using uncertainty and diversity sampling strategies is mentioned as one of the strategies in the course.

From the machine learning program, you will gain practical skills such as designing and writing code to build an end-to-end machine learning system from scratch, learning best practices to tackle significant challenges faced by machine learning engineers in real-world scenarios, and using techniques like active learning, distributed training, adversarial validation, human-in-the-loop deployments, model compression, test-time augmentation, and testing.
I don't know.

'Lifetime access' in the context of the program means that once you pay to join the program, you will have immediate access to every past, present, and future cohort. This means you can participate in as many iterations of the program as you'd like without any additional fees.

The program's live sessions for building machine learning systems include 18 hours of interactive sessions, 10 hours of step-by-step coding instructions, practice with 100 coding assignments, access to the complete source code of a production system, and the opportunity to start freelancing on Upwork.
To enroll in the program, one must pay a one-time fee of $500. There are no monthly fees, annual fees, or hidden costs associated with joining the program.

The resources and benefits provided upon enrollment in the machine learning program include:
1. 18 hours of live, interactive sessions
2. 10 hours of step-by-step coding instructions
3. A final project with direct feedback
4. 100 coding assignments and practice questions
5. Entire source code of a working production system
6. Private community collaboration
7. Direct access to the instructor
8. Lifetime access to past and future cohorts
9. Program certificate upon completion

Unique or exclusive materials:
- The entire source code of a working production system
- Lifetime access to past and future cohorts

These resources and benefits are provided to emphasize practical, hands-on learning in the program.

The practical skills you will acquire from the program include designing and writing code to build an end-to-end machine learning system from scratch, learning best practices to tackle significant challenges faced by machine learning engineers, using techniques like active learning, distributed training, adversarial validation, human-in-the-loop deployments, model compression, and test-time augmentation, as well as learning how to create training, deploying, monitoring, and inference pipelines using tools like Amazon SageMaker and open-source tools. These skills are applicable to real-world machine learning systems.

The upcoming Cohort 17 of the program will start on February 3, 2025, and end on February 20, 2025. The live sessions will take place every Monday and Thursday at 10:00 AM EST. On Wednesdays, there will be optional office hours.

The copyright for the materials made available is registered under Tideily LLC. The specific rights reserved are mentioned as "All rights reserved". The contact details mentioned are svpino@gmail.com.

The main subjects discussed in Session 1 of the program focus on production machine learning and project initiation strategies. Some of the key topics covered include:
1. The difference between production machine learning and theoretical learning.
2. Strategies to solve the right problem using the right solution.
3. Critical questions to ask before starting any project.
4. Problem framing, inversion, and the haystack principle for building successful applications.
5. The first rule of machine learning engineering and how to start building.
6. Data collection strategies.

These subjects are essential for understanding how to approach machine learning projects in a production environment and ensuring the successful initiation of a project.
You can access recordings of the live sessions from the Machine Learning School program if you are unable to attend them live and want to catch up asynchronously later.
The strategies for active learning highlighted in the course include uncertainty sampling and diversity sampling.

The exact start date for the upcoming cohort of the 'Building Machine Learning Systems That Don't Suck' program is February 3, 2025. The cohort will run from February 3 to February 20, 2025, with live sessions taking place every Monday and Thursday at 10:00 AM EST. This cohort is part of a 3-week program that offers 18 hours of hands-on, live training spread over the specified time frame.

In the context of the program, 'lifetime access' implies that participants only need to pay once to join and will have immediate access to every past, present, and future cohort. This means that they can benefit from updates and new iterations of the program without any additional costs.

Someone interested in coding should set aside 2 to 4 hours weekly to complete the code walkthroughs and work on the assignments in order to effectively participate in the course and implement the concepts discussed in class.

Participants in the program mentioned in the context will gain practical skills in building production-ready machine learning systems from the ground up. This program emphasizes inclusivity and accessibility by providing lifetime access to live, interactive sessions, step-by-step coding instructions, coding assignments, access to the complete source code of a production system, and the opportunity to collaborate with a community of thousands of people from different backgrounds. Additionally, participants will receive direct feedback and support from the instructor, making the program accessible to individuals with disabilities who may benefit from personalized assistance.
The strategies covered in the course for active learning, specifically in the context of addressing selection bias and ensuring data diversity, include uncertainty and diversity sampling strategies.

Yes, in the context of the program, 'lifetime access' means that participants will have ongoing access to all course materials and updates, even if they are unable to complete the program due to unforeseen circumstances.

The cost to join the program is a one-time payment, and the specific benefits or resources included in the fee are lifetime access to live interactive sessions, step-by-step coding instructions, a final project with direct feedback, coding assignments and practice questions, complete source code of a working production system, access to a private community, direct access to the instructor, and a program certificate upon completion.

Upon joining the machine learning program, you receive resources such as sessions on handling selection bias, dealing with labeling data, human annotations, natural labels, weak supervision, active learning using uncertainty and diversity sampling strategies, and techniques for determining the amount of data needed.
The next cohort for the 'Building Machine Learning Systems That Don't Suck' program is scheduled to begin on February 3 - 20, 2025.

The specific topics covered in the first session of the machine learning program include:
- How to start (almost) any project
- Understanding what makes production machine learning different
- Strategies to solve the right problem using the right solution
- Critical questions to ask before starting any project
- Techniques for problem framing, inversion, and the haystack principle
- The first rule of machine learning engineering
- Data collection strategies

For someone who prefers to watch recorded sessions at their own pace, these topics will be covered in the recorded session, allowing them to go through the content at their convenience.

The one-time payment structure for joining the program is $500. There are no additional costs associated with accessing advanced modules or resources, as the payment grants lifetime access to every past and future cohort without any monthly fees, annual fees, or hidden costs.

"Lifetime access" in this context means that once you pay to join the program, you will have immediate access to every past, present, and future cohort. This allows you to benefit from updates and improvements in each iteration of the program without having to pay again.

The topics covered in Session 2 of the course on the Machine Learning School Website include data cleaning, feature engineering, turning data into numbers using vectorization techniques, producing homogeneous features, handling missing values, choosing the best model, overfitting, hyperparameter tuning, experiment tracking, and measuring the quality of holdout set.

The cost structure for joining the program at the Machine Learning School is a one-time payment of $500 for lifetime access to all past and future cohorts. There are no monthly fees, annual fees, or hidden costs.

The program offers a practical, hands-on learning approach for machine learning. Participants are provided with lifetime access to 18 hours of live, interactive sessions, 10 hours of step-by-step coding instructions, a final project with direct feedback, 100 coding assignments, the entire source code of a working production system, a private community for collaboration, direct access to the instructor, lifetime access to past and future cohorts, and a program certificate upon completion.

Some key benefits offered by the program include lifetime access to past and future cohorts, 18 hours of live interactive sessions, 10 hours of step-by-step coding instructions, 100 coding assignments, access to the complete source code of a production system, feedback and support from the community, direct feedback from the instructor, and a program certificate upon completion.

The topics covered in the first session include:
- How to start (almost) any project
- The differences between production machine learning and traditional learning
- Strategies for solving the right problem with the right solution
- Critical questions to ask before starting a project
- Problem framing, inversion, and the haystack principle for building successful applications
- The first rule of machine learning engineering
- Data collection strategies

The focus of the 'Building Machine Learning Systems That Don't Suck' course is to help participants build production-ready machine learning systems from the ground up. The next cohort is scheduled to start on February 3 - 20, 2025.

Contact person: Santiago
Company name: Tideily LLC

You will gain practical skills in designing and writing code to build an end-to-end machine learning system from scratch. The unique aspects of the Machine Learning School program include learning best practices for tackling significant challenges faced by machine learning engineers in building, evaluating, running, monitoring, and maintaining machine learning systems in real-world scenarios.
The strategies discussed for active learning in the course include uncertainty and diversity sampling. The course covers techniques for handling missing values such as imputation techniques.

The cost structure for joining the machine learning program is a one-time payment with no monthly or annual fees. The program is designed for technical professionals such as software engineers, data scientists, data analysts, machine learning engineers, technical managers, and anyone who wants to use machine learning to solve real-world problems.

The instructor of the program is Santiago, a machine learning engineer with over two decades of experience building and scaling enterprise software and machine learning systems.
